Author: yuki yoroshi
Review:
A temple of the Rinzai sect in Sagano, Kyoto.
This temple, which has a reputation for the beauty of autumn leaves, has been introduced many times in media such as TV, magazines, and books. Pictures of gardens are often used in jigsaw puzzles and calendars. In addition, even outside the fall foliage season, seasonal flowers bloom and you can enjoy the tasteful garden.
Hokyo-in Temple was built during the Heian period as an imperial temple of Emperor Shirakawa (1053-1129). Chokuganji refers to temples built by imperial decree to protect the nation and provide peace of the body, such as Todaiji, Daianji, and Yakushiji.

Hokyo-in was not called 'Hokyo-in' from the time it was built, but was originally called 'Zenyu-ji.' From the end of the Heian period to the Kamakura period, several generations of members of the imperial family entered the temple and became chief priests.

During the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (1345-1350), Mokuan Shuyu Zenji, a high-ranking disciple of Muso Kokushi, joined the temple and restored the declining temple. At this Zennyu-ji Temple, he actively educated his disciples, and since then it has become a temple of the Rinzai sect.

Yoshiakira Ashikaga, the second shogun of the Muromachi Shogunate, lost his mother in 1365. At the memorial service, he listened to a lecture on the scriptures from Mokuan, and after participating in Zen meditation, he converted to Mokuan. Then, for his teacher's sake, he devoted himself to the maintenance of the monastery of Zennyu-ji Temple.

At that time, the main gate, temple gate, and Buddhist hall were built in a straight line from east to west. rice field. The location of the temple has not changed from its current location according to the "Oei Kyunmeizu" (a layout map of temples in the Saga area in the early Muromachi period).

In 1367, Yoshiakira died at the age of 38, and Zennyu-ji Temple became his family temple. In the era of Yoshimasa, the eighth shogun, the name of the temple was changed to Hokyo-in, after Yoshiakira's name, Hokyo-in. There were temple territories in Bitchu and Suo, and the temples were also prosperous thanks to the protection of successive generations of the Ashikaga shogunate. However, after the Onin War, temples declined along with the decline of the shogunate. This is because the temple estate was also embezzled, and it became economically difficult.

During the Edo period, Hokyo-in became a sub-temple of Tenryu-ji Temple, and the gate was located facing south, unlike today.
The temple was abandoned at the end of the Edo period, but was rebuilt after fifty years.

Mokuan became acquainted with Kusunoki Masatsura, a military commander of the Southern Court in Kawachi Province, and entrusted him with his affairs.

In the first month of 1348 (1348), Masayuki fought against a large army of the Northern Court led by Moronao Ko at the Battle of Shijonawate and died (at the age of 23). rice field. Later, when Yoshiakira heard this story from Mokuan, he praised Masayuki's character and asked him to be buried next to him.

In 1891 (Meiji 24), the governor of Kyoto, Kunimichi Kitagaki, regretted that the ruins of Konan (Masatsuyuki Kusunoki) were buried in secret, and in order to inform the world about this, he created a stone monument "Kinchuhi", which describes the origin of the burial mound for heads. ‚Äô was built.

In order to protect the ruins related to Kusunoki Masayuki, Hokyo-in Temple was rebuilt as a temple to mourn for Kusunoki Masayuki's soul, by Takagi Ryuen Tenryu-ji Temple head chief and Kobe businessman Yoshitaro Kawasaki.

The old precincts were repurchased, and the temple was refurbished by building new buildings and relocating old buildings.

The construction was completed in 1916, and the wooden standing statue of the eleven-faced, thousand-armed Kanzeon Bodhisattva (left photo) was welcomed as the principal object of worship. After that, the tea room was relocated and the current main hall was newly built.

Author: ÊùëÁî∞ÂíåÂΩ¶
Review:
19/12/1 Visit. Hokyo-in is of the Rinzai sect.
It is no exaggeration to say that there is nothing that can beat this one in terms of beauty among the many Karesansui gardens. I can only sigh.
It is also known for the grave of Masatsura Kusunoki's child, Masatsura.

The autumn leaves were coming to an end on this day, and I was planning to look around Sagano. I thought that if it wasn't first thing in the morning, there would be too many people, and I would end up looking at the people rather than the scenery, so I made it my first stop. About 10 people in line at 8:50... it's still okay.
Gates open at 9:00. If you enter from the back door on the right, the guide will guide you to the ticket vending machine. Buy a ticket and go inside from the entrance on the right. If you go to the left from there, you will see a spectacular view of autumn leaves. This is the best time to see the autumn foliage. Only this space has an atmosphere like a picture story, and it seems that time has stopped since peace.
If you haven't been here yet, you'll regret it for the rest of your life if you don't see this!

There is no parking lot. Please use the neighboring Seiryoji parking lot (800 yen per day) or coin parking.
There is one type of goshuin, and you can leave your goshuin book on the left side of the garden entrance (you need to enter). However, it is a stamp, not a direct writing...

Author: Yasuhiro
Review:
It is a temple of the Rinzai sect of Buddhism, and the mountain name is Zennyuuzan.
The autumn leaves in the garden are known to be very beautiful, but I don't like crowds, so I visit in the winter when the leaves are over.

The stone pillar at the temple gate says "Konanko Bodaiji".
Konanko is Masatsura, the eldest son of Masashige Kusunoki.
According to the tradition of the temple, the head of Masayuki, who was defeated in the Battle of Shijonawate, was buried in this temple by Mokuan, a disciple of Muso Kokushi, who Masatsura devoted himself to. In addition, it is said that Yoshiakira Ashikaga, who was an enemy of Masayuki, was buried in this temple according to his will.
The temple was called Zennyu-ji during the reign of Emperor Shirakawa, then changed to Kanrin-ji by Yoshiakira Ashikaga. .

Author: Neurodom 001
Review: Pay the admission fee at the temple office at the entrance, open the small door, and enter the garden. It has a lot of depth and is a very quiet space. I'm sure it will be gorgeous during the autumn leaves season. As a feature, there is no water, and rivers and ponds are expressed with gravel. If you go further inside, you will find Kubizuka. You can get a red stamp at the temple office, so please leave the red stamp book before entering the garden. There is no parking lot. There is a coin parking nearby, and there is also a paid parking lot at Seiryoji Temple. It might be a good idea to stop by on your way to Nison-in Temple from Seiryo-ji Temple.

Author: Rory Rosszell
Review: We just loved this garden! The trees are beautiful, but viewing them from the interior of the building through the open shoji adds a very nice element to their beauty. Interestingly, it is the only Japanese garden I have ever been to in which, rather than having the usual water, they created a meandering stream filled with white pebbles. There is even a waterless waterfall!

Author: ak
Review:
This historical temple was built in Sagano by Emperor Shirakawa during the Heian period. Located behind Seiryo-ji Temple, it is a relatively small temple, but the autumn leaves in the garden are wonderful.
When I passed through the gate, I was overwhelmed by the cobblestone pavement and the tunnel of autumn leaves. The gradation of autumn leaves dyed in red, yellow, and orange is beautiful. Green moss is planted vividly around the stone pavement.
The temple is famous for its beautiful autumn leaves in Sagano, so the autumn leaves season is not as crowded as around Arashiyama.

Visiting hours
9:00-16:00 (16:30 in November)

admission fee
Adult: 500 yen
Elementary and junior high school students: 200 yen

Author: Tadaaki Tokunaga
Review:
The scale is small, but as soon as you enter inside, the autumn leaves are full. Surrounded by autumn leaves. The highlight!
In Kyoto, I visited about 10 famous places for autumn leaves, but this was the best place for autumn leaves.

Author: Victor Wong
Review: Quite and beautiful red leaves

Author: Lisa B
Review: Such beautiful gardens to stroll through. Slightly off the beaten track, so not too busy. Amazing colours in autumn.

Author: Boyu Chen
Review:
I visited at the end of November, and I was not in the itinerary, but I saw that the maple leaf condition of Baokuangyuan was good that day. It is not too far from Lanshan Street, so I stopped by to have a look. The conclusion is that the trip is worthwhile!
The temple is not too big, but compared with other scenic spots in Arashiyama, it is less well-known and there are not so many people, so it will not be so crowded. Walking into the temple is like stepping into the red world. The yellow, yellow, red and red lines are very beautiful. , You can take off your shoes to pay homage to the temple. After the visit, sit on the tatami mats and enjoy the Japanese-style garden scenery outside the door. However, you can‚Äôt sit for too long to avoid hindering others from taking pictures. The 500 yuan ticket feels great value for money! If you come to Arashiyama, you might as well take a look here!

Review:
Hokyoin was built in the Heian period. Founded by Emperor Shirakawa in the Jowa era (1345~), it was restored by a monk named Shuyu Mokuan.

2023'1/25 snow
Visited for the first time. Reception after passing through the mountain gate, purchase a ticket from a vending machine (500 yen)
"Open the door over there and come in." The moment I opened the door, a voice leaked out! What a wonderful snowscape!

When I went to the main hall, one of the first young women was taking pictures. Since the seat was vacated, I put my hands on the principal image first. Young and beautiful, I called out to her on my way home.
‚ÄúDid you come for the snow scene?‚Äù ‚ÄúYes, the autumn leaves are also very beautiful.‚Äù The drooping cherry blossoms‚Ä¶ the corridors around here are full of people.‚Äù
"Also, the garden in front of me can't be seen because of the dry landscape and snow..." "Hey, I can see the road over there."

He told me that he has been here many times, and he kindly told me to open the shoji screen and take good pictures. Thanks to that, the circuit garden where I stepped on the fresh snow, the sneakers got snowy, wet and cold!üòÇ

Author: Akira Adhikara
Review: Went to Hokyo-in Temple back in 2019. A humble temple which wasnt really known back then, with small numbers of foreign tourists were visiting. The ‚Äúmaple alley‚Äù was really superb and dense with orange and red maple leafs. Autumn foliage is the best to be seen in this temple.

Author: YUNCHING YANG
Review: An application is required for taking pictures with a large monocular, and there is no limit for mirrorless small monoculars, decimal digits or mobile phones. The area of ‚Äã‚Äãthe courtyard is small, and there are not many passages, so it is easy to photograph passers-by. Those who want to take good photos have to think twice. There are pass tickets for Baoyanyuan and Baohangyuan. If you can visit both places, you can buy a pass to save money. However, the notice of Baohangyuan is not obvious
